text: it's possible that a super drought drove
the settlers from their homes in search
of a water source but where did they go
now archaeologists have a fresh new take
on the one clue we know for sure they
left behind a single word carved onto a
gate post Croatoan there is evidence
that local natives actually reached out
to support the English colonists in
various ways including the chief of the
Croatoan Tribe Lost Colony expert Scott
Dawson is directly descended from that
tribe for me this is a Native American
story and I felt like the Croatoan don't
get their up and coming because they
played this major role in American
history and they've been kind of reduced
to this funny word on a treat to prop up
a mythology when there are real people
and a real place Croatoan is an island
just 50 miles away from Roanoke it's now
called Hatteras as far as the Native
American history on the island they have
always maintained that a group of white
people came here and assimilated they
were instructed to write down where they
relocated to and they wrote down that
they came here so it seems like an
obvious place to look
it's a compelling theory but what we
really need is evidence archaeological
evidence that they were here
archaeologist professor mark Horton
believes the missing evidence could be
hidden on Hatteras Island where new
excavations offer tantalizing clues this
is the famous Cape Creek site on
Hatteras Island it's an incredibly
important Native American site and
suggestion is that this is the place
where the lost colonists came to this is
for example it's got a hook and eye
closure it's the sort of thing that you
would use on an Elizabethan doublet or
good quality clothing and it really
shows that there were Europeans here
wearing doublet
there are really only two explanations
as to how these European items got here
one the residents of Jamestown were
trading these artifacts with the Native
American Indians or two they were
actually the artifacts of the Roanoke
colonists themselves in archeological
terms it's really difficult it's only 25
years that separate the two dating
techniques they're just not that
accurate so we really can't be sure and
thus there's no smoking gun
